skin_diseases.name: Acne
skin_diseases.overview: Acne is a common skin condition that occurs when hair follicles become clogged with oil and dead skin cells. It often causes pimples, blackheads, or whiteheads, and typically appears on the face, forehead, chest, upper back, and shoulders.
treatments: Lifestyle changes (e.g., proper skincare routine, avoiding triggers)

skin_diseases.name: Actinic Keratosis
skin_diseases.overview: Actinic keratosis is a precancerous skin growth caused by long-term exposure to sunlight. It appears as rough, scaly patches, usually on areas exposed to the sun, such as the face, ears, scalp, and hands.
treatments: Topical medications (e.g., fluorouracil cream, imiquimod cream)

skin_diseases.name: Benign tumors
skin_diseases.overview: Benign tumors are non-cancerous growths that can develop in various tissues of the body, including the skin. They typically grow slowly and do not invade surrounding tissues or spread to other parts of the body.
symptoms: No pain or discomfort (in most cases)
treatments: Surgical removal (if causing symptoms or concerns)

skin_diseases.name: Bullous
skin_diseases.overview: Bullous diseases are a group of rare skin conditions characterized by the formation of large fluid-filled blisters (bullae) on the skin or mucous membranes. These blisters can vary in size and may be caused by autoimmune reactions or genetic factors.
causes: Exposure to certain medications or chemicals
treatments: Wound care (to prevent infection and promote healing)
Treatments to suppress the immune system or remove antibodies (in severe cases)

skin_diseases.name: Candidiasis
skin_diseases.overview: Candidiasis is a fungal infection caused by the Candida yeast species. It can affect various parts of the body, including the skin, mouth, throat, genitals, and bloodstream. Skin candidiasis typically presents as a red, itchy rash with satellite lesions.
symptoms: Satellite lesions (smaller lesions surrounding the main rash)
causes: Overgrowth of Candida yeast on the skin
treatments: Antifungal creams or ointments (e.g., clotrimazole, miconazole)
Oral antifungal medications (for severe or recurrent cases)
Keeping the affected area clean and dry

skin_diseases.name: Drug Eruption
skin_diseases.overview: Drug eruptions are skin reactions caused by exposure to certain medications. These reactions can range from mild rashes to severe blistering and can occur shortly after starting a new medication or even weeks to months later.
treatments: Treatment of any underlying infection or systemic symptoms

skin_diseases.name: Eczema
skin_diseases.overview: Eczema, also known as atopic dermatitis, is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by dry, itchy, and red patches on the skin. It often occurs in individuals with a personal or family history of allergies, asthma, or eczema.
symptoms: Red to brownish-gray patches, especially on the hands, feet, ankles, wrists, neck, upper chest, eyelids, inside the bends of the elbows and knees
Small, raised bumps that may leak fluid and crust over when scratched
treatments: Topical corticosteroids or calcineurin inhibitors to reduce inflammation

skin_diseases.name: Infestations and Bites
skin_diseases.overview: Infestations and bites refer to various skin conditions caused by infestations of parasites (such as lice, scabies) or bites from insects or arachnids (such as mosquitoes, fleas).
treatments: Topical or oral medications to kill parasites (e.g., permethrin for scabies)
Proper wound care to prevent infection

skin_diseases.name: Lichen
skin_diseases.overview: Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that affects the skin, mucous membranes, hair, and nails. It presents as itchy, flat-topped, polygonal bumps that may be purple, violaceous, or pink in color.
symptoms: Wickham striae (white, lacy lines) within the lesions
causes: Hepatitis C virus infection (in some cases)
treatments: Oral medications (e.g., corticosteroids, retinoids) for severe cases

skin_diseases.name: Lupus
skin_diseases.overview: Lupus is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, heart, lungs, and brain. Cutaneous lupus erythematosus (CLE) specifically involves skin manifestations, which can range from mild rashes to severe lesions.
symptoms: Butterfly-shaped rash on the face (malar rash)
treatments: Systemic corticosteroids or immunosuppressants for severe cases
Sun protection measures (e.g., sunscreen, protective clothing)

skin_diseases.name: Moles
skin_diseases.overview: Moles are common skin growths that are usually brown or black in color. They can appear anywhere on the skin and vary in size, shape, and texture. While most moles are harmless, some may develop into melanoma, a type of skin cancer.
treatments: Surgical removal (if concerning features or changes are observed)

skin_diseases.name: Psoriasis
skin_diseases.overview: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin disorder characterized by the rapid proliferation of skin cells, resulting in thick, red patches covered with silvery scales. It commonly affects the scalp, elbows, knees, and lower back.
treatments: Biologic agents (e.g., TNF-alpha inhibitors, interleukin inhibitors)

skin_diseases.name: Rosacea
skin_diseases.overview: Rosacea is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that primarily affects the face, causing redness, visible blood vessels, and sometimes small, pus-filled bumps. It often begins with flushing or persistent redness on the central face and may worsen over time if left untreated.
causes: Abnormalities in the blood vessels or immune system
Triggers such as sunlight, stress, spicy foods, alcohol, or certain medications
treatments: Laser therapy (to reduce redness or remove visible blood vessels)
Avoiding triggers and proper skincare routine

skin_diseases.name: Seborrheic Keratoses
skin_diseases.overview: Seborrheic keratoses are common non-cancerous skin growths that appear as brown, black, or tan warty growths on the skin. They can vary in size and may have a stuck-on appearance.
treatments: Generally, no treatment is necessary unless the growth becomes irritated or bothersome
Surgical removal (for cosmetic reasons or if there is concern about cancer)

skin_diseases.name: Skin Cancer
skin_diseases.overview: Skin cancer is the abnormal growth of skin cells, typically caused by prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight or tanning beds. There are three main types: basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma.
symptoms: Changes in the size, shape, or color of moles or spots on the skin
New growths or sores that don't heal
Itching, tenderness, or pain in the affected area
treatments: Mohs micrographic surgery (for certain types of skin cancer)

skin_diseases.name: Sun_Sunlight_Damage
skin_diseases.overview: Sun damage refers to various skin changes caused by prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun. It can manifest as sunburn, premature aging (photoaging), or an increased risk of skin cancer.
causes: Exposure to UV radiation from sunlight
Lack of sun protection (e.g., sunscreen, protective clothing)
treatments: Prevention through sun protection measures (e.g., sunscreen, hats, seeking shade)
Topical retinoids or antioxidants to improve skin texture and appearance
Laser therapy or chemical peels for more severe sun damage

skin_diseases.name: Tinea
skin_diseases.overview: Tinea, also known as ringworm, refers to a group of fungal skin infections that can affect various parts of the body, including the scalp (tinea capitis), body (tinea corporis), groin (tinea cruris), feet (tinea pedis), and nails (tinea unguium). It is characterized by red, itchy, circular patches with raised edges.
symptoms: Red, scaly patches with raised edges
Clearing or central healing of the rash
treatments: Oral antifungal medications (for severe or widespread infections)
Keeping the affected area clean and dry
Avoiding sharing personal items (e.g., towels, clothing) with infected individuals

skin_diseases.name: Vascular Tumors
skin_diseases.overview: Vascular tumors are abnormal growths that arise from blood vessels or lymphatic vessels. They can be benign or malignant and may occur anywhere on the body.
symptoms: May be red or blue in color
causes: Abnormal growth of blood vessels or lymphatic vessels
treatments: Chemotherapy or targeted therapy (for malignant tumors)

skin_diseases.name: Vasculitis
skin_diseases.overview: Vasculitis is a group of diseases characterized by inflammation of blood vessels, which can affect vessels of any size or type. Depending on the type and location of the blood vessels involved, vasculitis can cause a wide range of symptoms.
symptoms: Pain or tenderness in affected areas

skin_diseases.name: Vitiligo
skin_diseases.overview: Vitiligo is a skin disorder characterized by the loss of pigment-producing cells (melanocytes), resulting in white patches on the skin. It can occur at any age and may affect any part of the body.
symptoms: Loss of color in the mucous membranes (e.g., lips, eyes)

skin_diseases.name: Warts
skin_diseases.overview: Warts are benign skin growths caused by infection with the human papillomavirus (HPV). They can appear anywhere on the body and vary in size and appearance depending on the type of HPV involved.
symptoms: Black dots (clotted blood vessels) in the center
May cause pain or discomfort (especially on pressure points)
causes: Direct contact with an infected person or surface
treatments: Immunotherapy (e.g., injection of antigens to stimulate the immune system)
